author: sky.cactus
content: <@&595685821026271242> I think we need to find a solution to the reorg discussion location problem.  Specifically, we need a consistent story to tell people that pop in here asking about it.  Whether that is just "not here" or "in this specific channel" or "this ethresear.ch thread" I think matters less than having a response.  We seem to be getting overwhelmed with inquiries about it and desire to discuss it but we don't have a consistent place to redirect those users to.

author: pmcgoohan
content: Thats an old version. How about Plain Alex, Micah. Brings structure to the mempool. A single picker orders how they like. Way easier to implement. 40% reduction in exploitative MEV

content: Yes, they have a choice of 150000txs. Plain Alex pickers get a choice of 70txs. Hence 40% reduction in MEV

author: sky.cactus
content: If reducing block time was something we could do without consequence, we would just reduce the blocktime.

author: sky.cactus
content: And the *reasons* we don't reduce the blocktime will be the same reasons we cannot have frequent more frequent picking.

author: pmcgoohan
content: Yes you can't because of all the overheads of attestation etc. Don't have those in the content layer

author: sky.cactus
content: Network propagation, for example, is an issue in any system.

author: ghosts_in_the_code
content: It can built as a second layer whose breakdown just goes back to status quo

author: sky.cactus
content: Complexity is another, any significant increase in complexity needs to bring with it pretty significant benefits, and changing frequency of transaction order selection doesn't feel like it brings enough benefits to matter.

author: ghosts_in_the_code

author: pmcgoohan
content: Putting us on a path to fix mev doesn't matter?

author: sky.cactus
content: Putting us on the path of, "you can't 'fix' MEV at layer 1 without making sacrifices we are unwilling to make at layer 1".

author: sky.cactus
content: There are solutions that individual protocols can implement like commit reveal schemes for example.

author: sky.cactus
content: For some applications, these make a lot of sense.  ENS does commit-reveal to prevent front running and it works really well.

author: pmcgoohan
content: Yes of course. Fbs can even run an auction (if they're fast enough), but I've done the analysis. By giving pickers less choice than miners most exploitative mev is reduced by 40%

author: sky.cactus
content: We don't want to require commit reveal at layer 1 though because the UX downside of it is not worth it for many platforms/apps/users.

author: sky.cactus
content: What is the elevator pitch for why you believe that having a smaller pool of things to choose from will reduce MEV?

author: sky.cactus
content: There are some extremely advanced MEV strategies that involve doing whole block organization that may work less, but I don't think anyone is actually doing this.  I *think* it would require a full AI to.

author: sky.cactus
content: Not reorgs, just orgs.  ðŸ™‚

author: sky.cactus
content: Meaning, there are theoretic strategies where you extract value from a block by optimally sorting every transaction in the block in a way that maximizes the amount of value you can extract.  This is different than current frontrun/backrun/sandwich things that generally look at one or two transactions to extract value from at a time.

author: sky.cactus
content: A sandwich happening 2 minutes after a transaction was sent usually just means there was minimal value to extract or there was a long block.

author: ghosts_in_the_code
content:
not theoretic ... CEX arbs already happening. 
And if we're forward looking to eth2 .. then the CEXes might directly own the very validators whose block txs theyre arbing against

author: sky.cactus
content: More frequent blocks wouldn't have prevented that sandwich if it was worth sandwiching.

author: ghosts_in_the_code
content: yup but thats just sandwich

author: pmcgoohan
content: Yes they would because the victim tx only became value after 2 mins, otherwise by definition it would have been sandwiched before

author: sky.cactus
content: 1 second transaction batches either won't work or will result in *massive* churn because network propagation time is significantly longer than 1 second.

author: sky.cactus
content: The victim transaction still would have sat in the pending pool for 2 minutes just the same.

author: pmcgoohan
content: Yeah I said 1 to 3 secs

author: sky.cactus
content: Even 3 seconds is likely too fast for network propogation.

author: pmcgoohan
content: No, its execution order would be guaranteed after 3 secs

author: sky.cactus
content: Things are probably faster these days, but it used to be that network propagation was around 6 seconds.

author: pmcgoohan
content: I think its a lot faster now, like a couple of 100ms

author: sky.cactus
content: The victim transaction sat in the pending pool for 2 minutes because its gas price was too low to be included.  No miner was willing to include that transaction over any other transaction.

author: sky.cactus
content: It definitely is not!  It takes something like 250ms just to direct-connect round trip via neutrino from one side of the planet to the other.  ðŸ˜„

author: sky.cactus
content: It is literally physically impossible to have global transaction propagation be faster than the speed of light around the planet.  ðŸ˜„

author: sky.cactus
content: Well, given our current understanding of physics.

author: pmcgoohan
content: Sure that's probably a bit low,  but not the point, I was talking about 3 secs

author: sky.cactus
content: Maybe something with entangled quantum particles we can do better one day.  ðŸ˜‰

author: sky.cactus
content: Reality is also way more complicated then theory.  For a transaction or block to propogate, it has to hope between nodes in a global peer to peer network and each node has to do a non-trivial amount of validation of the block before propogating.

author: pmcgoohan
content: There we have it, users now have to wait until their txs become exploitable to get included

author: ghosts_in_the_code
content: yup you need to shrink the validator set. which is fine for L2

author: sky.cactus
content: On a "normal" computer I think block validation takes on the order of hundreds of milliseconds, which means each hop in the network takes network travel time (which is non zero) and validation time (which is non zero).  If you assume 10 hops between any two points in the network, this whole process takes a while.

author: sky.cactus
content: If you are talking about having *all* transactions (regardless of gas price) be sorted by this system, then it opens the system up to attack vectors where people spam it with low gas price transactions that aren't actually likely to be included.

author: sky.cactus
content: My recommendation is to put together a complete proposal that lays everything out.  Then iterate on that to pair it down to the most simple solution possible.  The problem is that I have seen dozens of "solving MEV" proposals and they all are flawed (usually in a pretty common set of ways).  This, unfortunately, makes it hard to get eyes on new proposals because it becomes an increasing time sink to look at and debunk every proposal that comes through.

author: sky.cactus
content: *Maybe* you have some clever solution that no one has thought of before (despite lots of people thinking about it) but convincing people of that is a really hard problem due to the low signal to noise ratio on this particular topic.

author: sky.cactus
content: The more you can do do simplify your solution in as few words as possible (without leaving big open questions) the better.

author: sky.cactus
content: I recognize this is not ideal, but it is the reality of the world we live in unfortunately.

author: sky.cactus
content: As an example, I pretty much ignore all "MEV Solution" proposals now because it has become just too much of a time sink to bother reading them (I'm not even bothering to debunk them anymore).

author: pmcgoohan
content: Yeah I get it, and I will be. Only having a doc for the random version is not helping the cause

author: sky.cactus
content: Something that helps encourage me personally to evaluate a proposal is seeing that the author really *gets* the underlying problem up front.  Many authors of such proposals seem to fail to fully grok the situation which is what leads them to insufficient solutions.  If I see a proposal that makes it very clear that the author groks the problem at a very fundamental level I am more likely to read further than if an author makes some high level claims that suggests they may not fully grok the problem.

author: sky.cactus
content: I can't say how exactly to express this deep intuitive understanding of the problem in an introduction paragraph, but it is one of those things where in the past I "know it when I see it".

author: pmcgoohan
content: Maybe opening with the fact that I discovered MEV in 2014 might help ðŸ˜… But yeah- good idea. That's helpful thanks

author: sky.cactus
content: "MEV" has been around since basically the dawn of finance, so 2014 is pretty recent.  ðŸ˜‰

author: pmcgoohan
content: No it hasn't!

author: sky.cactus
content: Its presentation has changed over time as technology has changed, but the core of it has always been there.  It is an information and speed asymmetry problem.

author: sky.cactus
content: If I have information about what you are going to do in the future, I can exploit that knowledge to take some action.

author: sky.cactus
content: For example, if I know that you have a caravan full of silks from across the country on the way to a city before the silks arrive, I can offload all of my silks onto the market before you get there.

author: pmcgoohan
content: No other market in history has allowed visibility of 100000s of txs and a lone actor to pick and reorder 100s of them at once!

author: sky.cactus
content: Inversely, if I know you have a representative on the way to the city to buy a large amount of silks, I can buy up all the silks in town before you get there.

author: sky.cactus
content: Technology has only changed the speed and volume at which this sort of information asymmetry can be exploited.  It hasn't created a new class of information asymmetry.

author: sky.cactus
content: The same is true for arbitrage (you buy all the silk from city A, I quickly go buy silk from city B and bring it back to city A and sell it at a profit).

author: pmcgoohan
content: Rationalizations Micah. Ethereum is worse at markets than centralized regulated competitors. When I explain the situation to my mates in finance they either literally drop their jaws or lol. If the core devs cannot appreciate the severity of this problem then Ethereum is ngmi

author: sky.cactus
content: Centralized markets just create privileged actors who have the capability to exploit certain classes of information while everyone else doesn't.  They then utilize external systems (threat of violence via legal system for example) to try to disincentivize those privileged actors from exploiting their power.

author: sky.cactus
content: Which sometimes works, sometimes doesn't.  At the least, it creates an avenue for corruption that can (and is in some countries) heavily exploited by politicians and regulators for personal gain.

author: sky.cactus
content: This circles back to the ethos of Ethereum and crypto-currencies in general, which is to remove privileged roles from the system.  Everyone has equal rights and any specific roles/responsibilities that a particular actor has has as low as possible of a barrier to entry so anyone can take up that role.

author: pmcgoohan
content: Yes. We call them miners. Good to chat. I've got to go and put the porridge on!

author: sky.cactus
content: Maintaining this ethos often means we have to make decisions that cause us to do a worse than a centralized solution along some axis.  A perfect example of this is speed.  A centralized platform can execute transactions in milliseconds, while it takes us many seconds to do the same thing.  This is the price we pay for removing privileged actors from the system.

author: ghosts_in_the_code
content:
I agree that removing privileged actors is the current ethos, ... But Im not sure it should be that way, with having most priority. 

Imo highest priority is removing tail risk. Trusted relationships are only bad imo because if they break down there's adverse consequences. But probability of breakdown is usually low. Crypto provides more transparencies into the modes of breakdown, which in turn can be used to design better and remove these in the first place. Transparency also promotes knowing what the breakdown modes and likelihoods of occuring are in the first place, even if they cannot be removed. This is more beneficial than say a judicial system (how much does it cost to DDOS a court with meaningless cases? How far do social incentives need to be engineered to bribe a court? Nobody knows)


If you can clearly define who the trusted actors are and what degree of trust you're placing, you also have the side benefit of sometimes being able to make it non-privileged (for instance once you realise incentives and trust for a single block producer you can rotate it using PoW or PoS). But idk if this is a the primary goal.

author: sky.cactus
content: If you are OK with privileged actors in a system, then there are *way* better solutions to transparent finance than a blockchain like Ethereum.

author: ghosts_in_the_code
content: Ethereum has semi-privileged actors, i.e., miners. Rollups will increase the privilege via their block producers.

author: sky.cactus
content: The vast majority of the hard problems and usability discomfort found in crypto-currencies comes from the lack of privileged actors.

author: sky.cactus
content: These aren't privileged actors, they are incentivized actors.  Anyone can take on that role without anyone else's permission.

author: sky.cactus
content: A privileged actor is someone who has permission/access/responsibilities that someone else cannot take on should they wish to due to some artificial constraint.

author: ghosts_in_the_code
content: Broadly that's true for any system. Anyone can become a judge. Anyone can become a politician. Question then is barrier for entry, trustworthiness / trustlessness once they get the position, incentives, etc

author: ghosts_in_the_code
content: Can't run performant systems without privileged actors imo ... You can only reduce the degree of trust and control you place in such actors

author: sky.cactus
content: You cannot anonymously become a judge, and you cannot become a politician without people approving you to become one.

author: sky.cactus
content: Which is exactly why Ethereum is not a performant system.  ðŸ™‚

author: ghosts_in_the_code
content: Yup but I'd want to build or see built .. performant systems on ethereum or using similar tech :)

author: ghosts_in_the_code
content: Can be more  ambitious

author: sky.cactus
content: If you are willing to accept privileged actors you can do way better than a traditional blockchain.

author: ghosts_in_the_code
content: Anything significantly better than status quo is worth building, doesn't have to eliminate privileged actors altogether

author: sky.cactus
content: I think the reason people like Binance copy Ethereum is mainly for marketing and laziness.  You could do significantly better by just having a publicly readable journaling database with signed transactions.

author: sky.cactus
content: All the performance of traditional internet systems, with all of the transparency of a blockchain.

author: ghosts_in_the_code
content: Who runs the database?

author: sky.cactus
content: The privileged actor of your choice.  ðŸ™‚

author: sky.cactus
content: If all you want from a blockchain is transparency, this is a great solution.

author: ghosts_in_the_code

author: ghosts_in_the_code

author: sky.cactus
content: A while back I came up with a Proof of Benevolence idea for sorting.

author: sky.cactus
content: Essentially the system was centrally sorted (centralized DB more or less), but individual users ran copies of the DB.  If at any point the centralized sorter did anything untoward the client would disconnect from them.  It even had a mechanism for dealing with censorship.

author: sky.cactus
content: The idea was that as long as the centralized DB operator behaved honestly, the blockchain would run with the performance of a centralized system.  If the operator ever behaved maliciously (in a detectable way), then everyone would disconnect and the chain would halt until a new central provider was found.

author: ghosts_in_the_code
content: dPoS?

author: sky.cactus
content: The theory is that central providers turning malicious is very unlikely when there is a credibly threat of chain halt should they do so, so you don't actually have to have a system for handling automatic failover.

author: sky.cactus
content: I feel like dPoS is too complicated for achieving the same goals.

author: sky.cactus
content: Proof of Benevolence is incredibly simple, comparatively speaking.  By getting rid of the automatic failover you lose that property, but that is a property that you may never actually need, and you can do human manual failover when it happens.

author: sky.cactus
content: This isn't ideal for all situations, but I think for a *lot* of things it is a very simple and easy to grok solution.

author: sky.cactus
content: It gives you transparency and trustless interactions at the cost of ___ (forget the word, guaranteed uptime) to a particular attack vector.

author: ghosts_in_the_code
content: Yup, definitely along the lines of what I'm looking for .. except average users may not be able to store or run

author: ghosts_in_the_code
content: Or even just store

author: ghosts_in_the_code
content: If DB too big

author: sky.cactus
content: You would still need to solve the state growth problem in this model.

author: sky.cactus
content: Though, I think Ethereum R&D has made great progress on this front and you could use very similar techniques.

author: ghosts_in_the_code
content: So this is just sharding + optimistic rollup?

author: sky.cactus
content: And they are much easier when you design them into the system from the start.  They are hard for Ethereum partially because we are trying to add them in to a running system.

author: ghosts_in_the_code

content: State expiry and portal network.

author: sky.cactus

author: sky.cactus
content: I am a big fan of zkRollups, and a mild fan of ORs.

author: sky.cactus
content: I would much rather see that complexity moved to layer 2 solutions like zkRollups and we use the base layer just for settlement of layer 2s.
